div.head: To the Editor of the "North-China Herald."
div.p: Mr. Editor,—In looking over a late file of California papers my attention was arrested by a call for a public meeting to take into consideration “ the necessity of urging upon the central government, the establishment of a line of Steamers across the Pacific ocean,” and as one of your correspondents, in the last number of your paper has availed of your columns to give publicity to a few very sensible remarks respecting our present Steam communication, it has occurred to me a few words, at this time, upon this projected Pacific line might not be unaccepta-
ble.

Dependent as we are now, upon the orders of a single Board of Directors for what few facilities we enjoy, I fancy there are but few of our Community who would not like to see the time when the appearance of a Steamer in our port, might be looked upon as a weekly certainty instead of a monthly, possibility : there appears but little likelihood, that any Company will start up in the west, to rival the present monopolisers of the Indian Steam communication, and until our port becomes of sufficient importance to make it an object to keep a Steamer on the coast, we are liable at any time

to be deprived of what is now allotted us. Sincerely hoping such may not he the case let us turn our attention eastward and see what has been done, and what is proposed to be done, in our behalf. It has been the general impression among foreigners in China for sometime past, that we were to have a line of Steamers across from California though probably but few are aware that any very decided steps have ever been taken, to bring this about. Shortly after the close of the Mexican War (in December 1848) this matter was brought before the American Congress, and the Committee to whom it was referred reported so favourably upon it, that oilers were issued to the Commanders of the Pacific and East India Squadrons, to ascertain, what quantity of coals might be obtained in the vicinity of the proposed route : the Commander of the first named fleet could only report what was already known that an abundance of coals might be obtained from Vancouver’s Island and its vicinity, but the scarcity of laboring men, for California, rendered these mines useless.
Upon the receipt of the order in China the brig Dolphin was sent to the only known coal mines of any extent in our vicinity, to Kelung, on the north end of Formosa : but little difficulty was ex-

perienced in finding the mine which they reported as situated near the bank of the river twelve miles from the anchorage, that it would probably yield an all sufficient supply of coals of very good quality (in appearance much resembling the Kennel Coal) but the right of working the mine was claimed by the Governor of Fokeen province, without whose consent it would be useless to attempt to get any : the pecul of coals brought away, cost them 10 dollars, and the Committee appointed by Congress, apparently disgusted at the price of fuel in our parts, rendered their report and quietly retired. Since that time the many more important matters to be arranged, have quite set aside the reconsideration of this to us important topic ; until our kindred across the water, weary of slavery debates, have gathered together and cried out to Congress to attend to them : it may be leaning upon rather a weak reed, but we have strong hopes that even if nothing is done upon this side, the energy and perseverance of the citizens of San Fran-sisco will yet accomplish much in this matter.

At the rate at which the distance between Panama and San Francisco is accomplished at present, it would require about 25 days between the latter place and our port. It has been evident all along that some intermediate coal depot must be established upon some of the Islands in the Pacific and the Fox or Bonin isles were referred to in the meeting in San Francisco: but from what was stated there by the Captains of whalers, it appears that their open roadsteads and fog enveloped shores, are not likely to be the places most favourable : the evidence was so conclusive that a damper was evidently thrown upon the meeting until some one cried out Japan. We should regret to find that in those who attended this meeting the inborn desire of Americans to go west, had not been satisfied by a trip to California : although whatever they may do in the furthering the establishment of the line of steamers we trust may have its due effect.
It may be argued that there is no traffic to support such a line and without the assistance of Government it is allowed it would be a losing business. But when

it is borne in mind that San Francisco is now the depôt for Chinese goods for all the ports on the western coasts of America it will be acknowledged that the amount of Silk freight, would monthly be no inconsiderable amount. As it would be only on the finer and more expensive articles of merchandise such as Silks &c., that could afford to be sent in this manner, it appears that for a time our desired line of steamers would only serve to build up the trade of Canton, though from the fact that the manufactures there have reached their present pitch of excellence by the teaching of the foreigners with whom they deal, we should be well content in the long run to leave this matter in the hands of many of those around us.

It now only remains for us to enquire if something cannot be done from here in furtherance of this object. Our friends upon the other shore have taken the matter up as if they were not inclined to leave it and a voice from this quarter we have no doubt would be acceptable. In the debates in their meeting we find no allusion made to any on this unfortunate side who may benefit by their undertaking, or who are even watching their progress with feelings of interest. Apparently astonished at their own rapid advancement, they overlook the fact that there is a growing community on this side to whom the proposed plan is of much more real importance than even to themselves. It may be that a Circular for shares in such a company might meet with questionable success among us, but as yet we are called upon for no such display of enterprise, and a few words of encouragement to the citizens of California could do no harm, and would naturally give an increased interest to their proceedings. Hitherto we have been apparently unconcerned spectators of the progress of this movement but with a firm conviction that we can aid and assist the enterprise I have availed of your columns to bring the subject forward. With a proper appreciation of the talents of many of my countrymen, I am aware that all this would have been much better said by some one else, but if it only has the effect of bringing the matter into more general consideration it will gratify the wish of more then one.
American.

Grey Shirtings. — Since our last report, a speculative demand for Grey Shirtings, has given greater firmness to the market, and prices have advanced. The rise in low reeds and in 72s. may be quoted as from 6 to 12 cents, and in the medium qualities 64s. to 66s. fully 15 cents.

We estimate sales, since 18th ultimo, at about 85,000 pieces of Grey and 38,000 pieces of White.
Estimated stock in first hands—

Prospects are favorable for business after the Chinese Holidays now at hand. Looking to the comparatively small stocks of Grey Shirtings, the moderate quantity expected to arrive, and the satisfactory account from the interior, further improvement in prices may be anticipated. The low qualities of White Shirtings, having been of late imported in excess may probably continue depressed, till stocks become reduced. Its publication must not be accepted as an approval by us of his opinions; indeed if he be a party interested in the affair referred to; we think he ought to congratulate himself on the Consular lenity, exhibited on that occasion.

We admit that the Supplementary Treaty is of an exceptional character to the whole course hitherto of British policy; and may further add, that it imposes most unpleasant, but onerous duties on our Consuls; still the Treaty exists, and manifestly must be en forced, if public faith is to be kept with the Chinese Government.

div.head: The Condemnatory Edict Translation
div.p: The "condemnatory Edict” of which the following is a translation, first reached Shanghae about a fortnight ago. Since then, various versions of it have circulated among the respectable classes of natives, by whom it has been received as an authentic document,—an opinion which has at length been put beyond a question by its appearance in one of the last Pekin Reporters from which this translation has been made.

As the sentence of an Emperor condemning to irretrievable disgrace and degradation, the two statesmen of China to whom we have been accustomed principally to look with any shadow of hope for a more liberal feel ing towards "the foreigners from a far,” and as the first glimmering of

youthful successor, it conveys tidings of the deepest interest; while its sum mary and tyrannical character prepares us for further measures, which will no doubt in one way or other materially affect foreign intercourse with His Imperial Majesty's subjects.

Totally in the dark as to the movements of the political world at Peking, we cannot guess at the originating cause of so sudden and severe a con-.demnation of two men but lately enjoying their Sovereign's highest favor and implicit confidence, and, if one may judge from their position, possessed of unbounded influence. But the invidious comparison instituted by His Imperial Majesty between the patriotism of Tahunga，the butcher of our Formosan captives, the Haynau of China,—and the treason of Keying, the framer of our treaty and introducer of our commerce, leads us to believe that a party diametrically opposed to foreign interests has
gained the ascendancy in the Imperial councils. That this is the case seems pretty evident from the favor with which Lin is spoken of; and we know not what important influence the late
decease of that Enemy of England may have on the future proceedings of the Imperial Court. We have every reason to be anxious for the result.
We trust, however, that our authorities will not see fit to disregard this index of the Imperial policy towards us.

Documents such as this, though in the main but pompous effusions of ignorant conceit, go far to prove the true feelings and intentions cherished by China towards England, notwithstanding the solemn compact by which she is bound ; and, if not constantly and strongly animadverted upon, in the official communications with the Imperial Commissioner at Canton, their promulgators will gain fresh courage with every fulmination, and will, no doubt, eventually proceed to adopt measures deeply injurious to our general commerce, if not actually prejudicial to our position at the ports of trade.

Firm, decided, and timely expostulation may prevent, what it will take hostile measures in the end to cure; and it would be well if our Higher authorities were less ready to prove themselves wrong and our opponents faultless than a late proclamation supporting the prevarications of Commissioner Seu has shown them to be.
PEKING，10/A moon, 28th day. (Sunday Dec. 1st, 1850.)
A decree, condemnatory of Muhchanga and
K'eying, has been issued under the hand and seal
of His Imperial Majesty, couched in the following terms:—
The duty, which chiefly devolves upon the

Ruler of a people, is, on the one hand to nominate men of merit, and, on the other, to remove from office those who are devoid of all sound principle. But to perform the latter part of our duty with partiality will necessarily be at-tended by an indifferent execution of the former.

Looking at the prc«eut state of affairs, however, the Empire may be said to be in a woful state of decline; for the officials are, in the administration of Government, daily becoming more inef-ilcient, and the affections of the people are growing more and more estranged,

This doubtless is in a great measure Our own fault. Yet, We feel that, to assist us in the intricate task of electing for office those who are duly qualified, or rejecting those who are incompetent, is a responsibility that rests with our Ministers of state.,

Our Minister, Muhchanga, although he has been in high favour at Court during several sue-cessive Reigns, appears never to have thought that to embody our views and feelings in the ex-ecutive part of the Government, was his serious and solemn duty. His only aim seems to have been to secure to himself both rank and renown; and, with this end, he has stood in the way of the promotion of men of worth and injured the best interests of these realms. He is a man, in whose fidelity little confidence can be placed, for, assuming an obsequious demea-nour, he only seeks to effect his crafty ends ； and, being an individual of fictitious accomplishments, he with cringing servility succumbs in every instance to his Sovereign, hoping thereby to gain Imperial favor and influence. When our difficulties with the barbarians first arose, how painstaking was Muhchanga in ridding himself of all who happened not to be in his interest! The recollection of this fills us with burning indignation. A notorious instance of this occurred at that time when he was bent upon the ruin of Tah-hnng-nga and Yaou-yung who, by their fidelity and diligence in Government, were checks upon his policy ； while he lent all bis influence to support Keying —a man who, unblushingly and without scruple, co-operated with him in carrying out all his base schemes.
and prostitution of Imperial power are without parallel!

The deceased Emperor, our revered Parent, himself a pattern of the strictest integrity, had a nature that could only treat man with unsuspecting confidence, and Muhchanga fearlessly took advantage of this to secure his own selfish purposes. But, had the Superior Intelligence of our honoured Parent for a moment suspected the perfidy of that man’s heart, His Majesty would, without doubt, have visited him with condign punishment
This Muhchanga, still presuming upon our
grace and favor, has from first to last persisted in his irregularities.

On the 1st month of the present year, when we took the reins of Government, we found him, in transacting public business connected with the state, either undecided and unable to form an opinion, or doggedly silent and unwilling to give it, until at length in a few months, his wily policy gradually came to light For instance， when the ships of the English barbarians reached Tien-tsint he was exceedingly anxious to bring Keying forward as his Colleague in carrying out his purposes and again involving the subjects of these realms in bitter and disastrous turmoils.
Without a question then, he is a deep, dangerous intriguer, whose designs can never be easily fathomed.
Recently too when Pwan-she-gan and his party recommended Lihtsihscu to us, Muhchanga re-

peatedly assured us that Lintsihseu was disabled by infirmity and disease as to be entirely unfit for active duty； and, when we had determined to tend to Kwangse to crush the insurrections there, Muchanga persisted in throwing out his
suspicions that Lin would not be able to proceed
on his mission.
Muhchanga, then, by fictitious representations, has deceived us and kept us in ignorance of the real state of affairs around us. Herein lies the burden of his offence.
As for Keying, his unpatriotic and pusillani-

mous policy is to Us a matter of unmixed astonishment. When he was at Canton, for instance, he seemed only anxious to make our people subserve the interests of foreigners,—all the while overlooking the claims of his native country, Is not this evident from his proposal to throw open the gates of that city,一whereby he violated the principles of heaven, outraged the feelings of man, and all but introduced a series of innovations, the results of which it is beyond human power to divine.

Our late lamented Parent, however, having seen through the duplicity of the man, forthwith recalled him to the Capital ； and, although he did not at once discard him from his service, only awaited a fit opportunity for doing so.

Recently, during a private interview with Our-selves,一keying spoke freely to Us of the English Foreigners how they were to be dreaded, and strongly urged upon Us the necessity of a mild and conciliating policy, supposing that we were not aware that his knawish object was merely to secure rank and emolument for himself. Oh! how fallen and degraded is he；一the more he speaks, the more we discover this,一so that at last we have the same contempt for him that we should have for a wild yelping cur.
Muhchanga is a deep man, whom if is difficult to fathom: Keying is shallow and easily found out: but their crime is one and the same,一they have entailed disgrace and injury upon their country.

Were We, therefore, not to carry out the demands of the law,一would this be ruling the people with proper selfrespect ? would this be fulfilling the serious trust that has been put upon us by our Revered Parent ?

Yet, when we think of Muchanga, that he has been an old servant of the Crown, under three successive reigns,——we cannot endure the thought of bringing merited punishment upon him all at once. We, therefore, command that the sentence be commuted for the more lenient penalty of deprivation of all official rank and that henceforth he no longer be employed in the service of the State. And as to Keying, although he is destitute of all strength and firmness, yet he has been to some extent the creature of circumstances ；一 We command therefore that leniency be shown him likewise, and that he be degraded to the fifth rank, to await employment in one of the six Boards.

That these two individuals have been deceiving their Sovereign, while they have been promoting their own selfish interests, must be evident to the whole empire; and yet we have not treated them with severe rigour, although it has for a long time cost us intense anxiety of mind in deliberating how to adjudicate the case.
Surely then, it must be allowed by all that we have been driven to this last step by dire and painful necessity.

We trust, therefore, that in future the officials throughout these realms, whether high or low, civil or military, will all, under the influence of those noble principles derived from heaven, strive faithfully to maintain the dignity of their country, so that the indolence and chicanery so prevalent at the present day shall be in earnest and without delay renounced.
Let none be deterred by difficulties.
Let none seek only for ease.
Should any one have in view some great scheme that may be calculated to promote the wealth of tbe state and nation, let him not hesitate to lay it before us.
Heed not the claims of patronage, or the interests of partisanship ； but, in maintaining the principles of justice and integrity, act inde-
pendently of all others and with assiduity fulfil the responsibilities of your several stations.
Let this Our decree be proclaimed, far and wide, at home and abroad, for the information of all people.
A special edict.

div.head: Report from the Jews' Society
div.p: From a report the Jews’ Society of last year it appears that its Committee had it in contemplation to send a Missionary to the Jews in China ; in reference to which they say : “ Your Committee

have gladly availed themselves of the opportunity offered by the establishment of the Bishopric of Victoria, Hongkong, to make further inquiries respecting the Jews in China, and the practicability of esta-

appear to be peculiar difficulties in the way of the immediate realization of their wishes in this respect, and their present efforts, must be limited to a Mission of Inquiry, in which the Bishop has kindly promised his assistance. That munificent friend of Israel, Miss Cook, has placed in the hands of your Treasurer a sum sufficient to cover the amount of the expenses occasioned by the establishment of the Mission.”

The Bishop of Victoria，on his arrival in Hongkong entered into a correspon-dence with the Rev, W. H. Medhurst, in Shanghae, requesting his assistance towards procuring information about the Jews in China, and forwarding to him a string of queries on that subject. Mr. Medhurst revolved the matter in bis mind, and was prepared with a plan, which on the expected arrival of the Bishop in Shanghae he thought might be carried into execution. The plan was this : to send two trustworthy individuals to
府封 k'hae-fung-foo the city where the Jews were supposed to be, to make inquiries respecting their existence, and to bring down such information and docu-

ments as could be easily procurable. The persons he had in view were native Christians, trained under the auspices the London Missionary Society, one of them a literary graduate from 鎭江府 Chin-keang-foo, and the other a young man who bad been brought up in the Mission School at Batavia, could read and write English, and after having had his Christian character tested by long experience, had been already employed as a tract colporteur in the interior, and given every satisfaction.

On the arrival of the Bishop in Shanghae, the plan and the persons to whom it was to be intrusted were brought before his attention, while the journal kept by the young man on a previous tour, and written in English, was submitted to his inspection, "The Bishop was not long in perceiving the propriety of the measure, and the persons alluded to, were despatched accordingly. The name of the graduate was Tseang-yung-che, and that of the young-man K'hew-t'heen-sang. The latter, though the youngest in years, was made the principal agent in the affair, chiefly because from our long acquaintance with his character we could place most confidence in him, and because being able to write English he could give his own account of the journey, which would be immediately intelligible to the lady who had projected the scheme and advanced the funds.
On the 15th November last they started from Shanghae in a boat which was engaged to convey them directly to
Ts'hing-keang-poo, a town situat*-ed in the prefecture of Hwae-

gnan-foo, on the banks of the grand canal, where it joins the Yellow river: (Lat. 33.33. N., Long. 2.50 E. of Peking.) In order to reach this place they availed themselves of the grand canal, which pas-ses through the cities of Soo-chow,

常州 Chang-chow, and Chin-keang-foo, where it crosses the great river 洋子江 Yang-tsze-kcang, and pursues its course in a northerly direction past 楊州府 Yang-chow-foo, Kaou-yew, and 寶應 Paou-ying, until it reaches the Yellow river. Arrived at that point they had to pursue their journey by land, for which purpose they hired a cart, drawn by two mules, and following the course of the Yellow river, sometiems on the north bank, and at other times on the south, they reached the place of their destination. The travellers represent the Yellow river, as at that season rather shallow, insomuch that at one place it could be forded by means of a cart. Its banks, however, were very high, and frequent indications appeared of its having overflowed the same during the rainy season, as exhibited in the marshes and lakes which abound along its course, in the midst of which garden trees and the remains of ruined houses are to be seen. The country in the neighbourhood of the river is in Consequence but thinly peopled, and the few inhabitants that are left arc poor and miserable in the extreme. Places that figure on the map as district cities presented to the travellers nothing but an assemblage of thatched cottages, with the walls which once surrounded them entirely demolished, and a solitary gateway here and there, tp tell of what once existed. The roads were very rough, causing the cart to jolt excessively :they led sometimes along the top of the bank, and at other times pursued the bed of the stream, in those parts which had been left dry by the receding tide. Here the cart was knee deep in sand, and there tumbling over rugged stones. Their driver, whose good graces they were obliged to propitiate, insisted on starting every morning at three or four o’clock, which on the dark and cold winter days was anything but pleasant, and it was generally midday before they could reach

a place where refreshments were to be procured. At the close of the day they generally stopped to rest for the night, and yet with all those hours employed in travelling, they did not make above twenty or thirty miles a day. The cart sometimes went so slowly that the passengers were fain to get out and walk, which they did much faster than the mules. At length after a very tedious journey they arrived at K’hae-fung-foo (Lat. 34.55. N., Long. 1.50. W. of
Peking.)

They found many Mahomedans resid-ing there，who made no secret of their religion, but wrote on their sign-boards the faith to which they belonged. These Mussulmen were the principal tavern-keepers, and with one of them the travel-lers put up. Their first inquiry was for the Jews, whom they asked for under the designation of the

祧筋教 T’heaou-kin-keaou, or Pluck-sincw-religion; an appellation which had been assumed or assigned in consequence of their plucking the chief sinew of the legs of all animals slaughtered for food. See Gen. 32: 32、 The. Mahomedan host immediately in-lormed them of the existence of the people

in question, and directed them to their synagogue. As it was late in the evening, when they arrived, they deferred their visit to the next day: there was no eulty in finding it: but "oh how changed how fallen!" from the time when the Jesuit Missionanes visited it a century ago. The outer wall of the inclosure was broken down, the front gate choked up with rubbish, the monumental pillars, the in scription tablets, the stone balustrades in front of the temples, and various other ornamental appendages broken or pros-

trated，and the very walls of the temple in many places dilapitated. The side apartments which had been designed at Chapels in honour of the patriarchs but poorly served to afford shelter to the few wretched sons of Israel who were handled together to them, sleeping on the bare ground, with scarcely a rag to cover them and barely sufficient to support nature. So much indeed were they reduced in circumstances, that they had begun to dispose of the fallen bricks and prostrate timbers of which the various apartments once consisted, to procure for themselves the necessaries of life. Yea they had gone
so far as to sell a piece of the ground of the

inclosure by which the temple was sur-rounded to the neighbouring heathen" who were encroaching on iits precincts by their ever-enlarging pagan temples. Yet there was enough to shew what had been its former glory. The gateways and in-scriptions were still there: the holy place was in existence, and its interior was beautifully decorated with gorgeous painting and elaborate gildings. Our travel-lers entered the holiest of all, from which polluted feet oc not now debarred, and saw the tubes Containing the rolls of the law, which they unrolled and examined. These rolls, twelve in number, were each about thirty feet in length, by two or three in width, written on white sheep-skins, in a small character. But the room in which they were found was so dark that our travellers could not examine them thoroughly. Perhaps it may be asked, how it is that .strangers are now permitted to intrude into the holy precincts, when a century ago, the Jesuit Missionaries, backed with all the influence derived from the Imperial Court, were not allowed to enter, or examine the records. The reply to this is easy, and solves the difficulty they have had no rabbi for fifty years! and there is not one of the professors of Judaism, in the present day in K’hae-fung-foo, who can read one word of Hebrew. They have even discontinued the practice of circumcision, and our travellers conceived that in a dozen more years few or no traces of the Israelitish religion will there be found. They did what they could, however, to rescue what remained from oblivion : they gave money to the bystanders, and urged them to set up one of the two inscription tablets in front of the temple, which had fallen down. This they copied; as well as the writing that was traceable on the tablet that was still standing. They took down memoranda of all the inscriptions yet preserved over the door ways and in front of the temple: they even copied the Hebrew inscriptions in the interior of the build-

ing, which are found to correspond ex-actly with those given by the Jesuit Missionaries ;while they measured accurately the length and breadth of the buildings, and brought away a very Intelligible ground-plan of the whole inclosure, as well as of the interior of the principal building. The most important achievement, however, and that which may tell on the interests of religion and the science of biblical criticism is, the bringing away of eight Hebrew manuscripts: six of them containing portions of the Old Testament Scriptures: and two of them consisting of the liturgy used in the weekly services of the Hebrew people, and on holiday occasions ;in which latter documents also various portions of Scripture are to be met with. The portions of Scripture are from the 1st to the 6th chapters of Exodus, from the 38th to the 40th chapters of the same book, Leviticus 19th and 20th chapters , Numbers 13th, 14th and 15th chapters, Deuteronomy- from the 11th to the 16th chapters, with the 32nd chapter of that book. Various portions of the Pentateuch, Psalms, and Hagiographa occiar in the books of prayers, which have not yet been definitely fixed. The character in which these portions are written is an antique form of the Hebrew, with points. They are written on thick paper, evidently by means of a style, and the material employed, as well as the silk in which the books are bound exhibit marks of a foreign origin. Two Israelitish gentlemen, to whom they have been shewn in Shang-hae, say that they have seen such books in Aden ; and the occurrence here and there of Persian words, written with Hebrew letters, in the notes appended，seem to indicate that the books in question came originally from the western part of Asia, perhaps Persia or Arabia. There is no trace whatever of the Chinese character about them, and they must have manufactured entirely by foreigners residing in China, or who have come from a foreign country.
